[[File:Italic - Urn in the Shape of a Hut and a Door - Walters 482312.jpg|thumb|right|400px|[[Villanovan culture]] cinerary hut-urn, showing the likely shape of Romulus' Hut in Rome: a simple mud-and-straw shelter]] [[File:Rome-Palatin-fonds de cabanes.JPG|thumb|Iron Age hut foundations on the Palatine Hill considered to be the ''Casa Romuli'']] The '''''Casa Romuli''''' ("hut of Romulus"), also known as the '''''tugurium Romuli''''', was the reputed dwelling-place of the legendary founder and first king of [[Rome]], [[Romulus]] (traditional dates 771-717 BC).<ref name="Nardini1819">{{cite book|author=Famiano Nardini|title=Roma antica|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=-6U_AAAAYAAJ&pg=PA156|year=1819|pages=156–}}</ref> It was situated on the south-western corner of the [[Palatine hill]], where it slopes down towards the [[Circus Maximus]], near the so-called "Steps of [[Cacus]]".<ref>Dionysius I.79</ref><ref>Plutarch ''Romulus'' 20</ref> It was a traditional single-roomed peasants' hut of the [[Latins (Italic tribe)|Latins]], with straw roof and [[wattle-and-daub]] walls, such as are reproduced in miniature in the distinctive [[urns|funerary urns]] of the so-called [[Latial culture]] (ca. 1000 - ca. 600 BC).<ref>Cornell (1995) 51</ref><ref>Vitruvius II.1.5</ref>
Over the centuries, the ''casa'' was repeatedly damaged by fire and storms, but carefully restored to its original state on each occasion.<ref>[[Dionysius of Halicarnassus|Dionysius]] ''Ant. Rom.'' I.79</ref> Destruction by fire is recorded for 38 BC, as a result of a ceremony held inside the ''casa'' by the ''[[pontifices]]'' ("College of High Priests"), presumably a burnt sacrifice to Romulus in his deified state as the god [[Quirinus]], during which the altar-fire probably ran out of control.<ref>[[Cassius Dio|Dio]] XLVIII.43</ref> The last recorded fire was in 12 BC, on the death of [[Marcus Vipsanius Agrippa]], right-hand man of the first [[Roman emperor]], [[Augustus]] (ruled 30 BC - AD 14). On this occasion, the ''casa'' was apparently set on fire by some crows which dropped pieces of burning meat, again snatched from an altar, onto the thatched roof.<ref>Dio LIV.29</ref> It has been speculated that a ''tugurium Faustini'' on the Palatine recorded in the time of the emperor [[Constantine I the Great]] (ruled AD 312-37) was in reality the still surviving ''casa Romuli''.<ref>Platner (1929) ''Casa Romuli''</ref>
A second ''casa Romuli'' is recorded in the classical sources, on the [[Capitoline Hill]], probably a replica of the original. It is last mentioned in AD 78.<ref>Vitruvius II.1.5</ref><ref>Platner (1929) ''Casa Romuli''</ref>
To date, archaeologists have been unable to definitively associate the ''casa Romuli'' with any extant remains.<ref name="PensabeneFalzone2001">{{cite book|author1=Patrizio Pensabene|author2=Stella Falzone|title=Scavi del Palatino I: l'area sud-occidentale del Palatino tra l'età protostorica e il IV secolo a.C., scavi e materiali della struttura ipogea sotto la cella del Tempio della Vittoria|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=Fa6zugozXqMC&pg=PA81|year=2001|publisher=L'ERMA di BRETSCHNEIDER|isbn=978-88-8265-119-0|pages=81–}}</ref> A strong candidate is the largest of a group of dwellings whose foundations were unearthed in the appropriate location during excavations in 1946. The dwelling's foundations were cut into the [[tufa]] bedrock, with an ovoid 4.9m X 3.6m perimeter. Six post-holes arranged in a circle of which one in the centre were presumably to accommodate the supporting struts for walls and roof respectively. Organic material found in the site has been dated to the Italian early [[Iron Age]] (ca. 900-700 BC).<ref>ArcheoGuida ''Casa Romuli''</ref>

It is part of group of religious buildings that include the Royal Church, and originally built by the [[Visigoths]] in the 7th century, in the form of a [[Greek cross]]. Since 1944, it has been classified as a [[National Monument]] ({{lang-pt|Monumento Nacional}}).<ref name=":0">{{Cite web|url=http://www.patrimoniocultural.gov.pt/pt/patrimonio/patrimonio-imovel/pesquisa-do-patrimonio/classificado-ou-em-vias-de-classificacao/geral/view/70191/|title=Capela de São Frutuoso|last=|first=|date=|website=www.patrimoniocultural.gov.pt|archive-url=http://www.patrimoniocultural.gov.pt/pt/patrimonio/patrimonio-imovel/pesquisa-do-patrimonio/classificado-ou-em-vias-de-classificacao/geral/view/70191/|archive-date=2018-03-26|dead-url=|access-date=2018-03-26}}</ref>
==History== [[File:Igreja de São Frutuoso (Em Real perto de Braga)1523.jpg|170px|left|thumb|The Church of São Francisco and the lateral Chapel of São Frutuoso, with dependencies associated with the Monastery of São Salvador, as seen from the square]] [[File:Alçado lateral Sul do templo.jpg|thumb|170px|left|The alternating exterior angular and rounded frieses on the southwest corner of the Chapel]] [[File:Interior. Pormenor de uma das arcadas triplas que antecedem três das quatro ábsides.jpg|thumb|170px|left|The triple horseshoe-shaped arch division between the arms of the Chapel]] Based on historical accounts, and oral tradition, the site of the chapel was (around 560 A.D.) the location of a small Roman villa and, likely, a temple dedicated to the god [[Asclepius]].<ref name="SIPA">{{cite web|url=http://www.monumentos.pt/Site/APP_PagesUser/SIPA.aspx?id=1903 |editor=SIPA |publisher=SIPA – Sistema de Informação para o Património Arquitectónico |title=Capela de São Frutuoso de Montélios/Capela de São Salvador de Montélios |location=Lisbon, Portugal |language=Portuguese |year=2004 |accessdate=2 July 2011 |first=Isabel |last=Sereno |first2=Paulo |last2=Dordio |first3=Joaquim |last3=Gonçalves |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131203072716/http://www.monumentos.pt/Site/APP_PagesUser/SIPA.aspx?id=1903 |archivedate=3 December 2013 |df= }}</ref>
In 656, [[Fructuosus of Braga]], then Bishop of Bracara, founded on this site the Monastery of São Salvador, ordering the construction of the chapel, as his tomb. In the biography of his life, São Valerius confirms as much, mentioning that the saint who founded the convent was buried there (between 665 and 666).<ref name=SIPA/>
In the 9th-10th century, the chapel was reconstructed and redecorated.<ref name=SIPA/> From a document dated in 883, the chapel was reconsecrated to ''São Salvador'', also affirming the original construction to between 656 and 665.<ref name=SIPA/>
Around the 12th century, following the [[Reconquista]] from the Arabs, with the revival of the Christian community and affinity for ''Saint'' Frutuoso of Braga, a cult to the saint was begun. In 1102, the [[Archbishop]] of [[Santiago de Compostela]], [[Dom (title)|D.]] Diogo Gelmires, transferred the mortal remains of Frutuoso to Compostela.<ref name=SIPA/>
In 1523, Archbishop [[Dom (title)|D.]] Diogo de Sousa founded the [[Franciscan]] convent of the Order of the ''Capuchos da Piedade'', alongside the chapel of São Frutuoso, likely destroying the older Monastery of São Salvador.<ref name=SIPA/>
From notes by [[friar]] Manuel de Monforte (in 1696), in his ''Crónica da Província da Piedade'' (''Chronicle of the Province of Piedade''), the chapel ''"is in [the shape of a cross] with all sides equal; whose points form four chapels, whose walls close in a half-circle. One of the chapels, which one can call the foot of the cross, serves as the entrance where the door is; another which rightly corresponds to this one, as the head of the cross, serves as the principal chapel, or where the altar is; in the other two, which are the arms, are the two collateral altars; having both about 17 palms, and half a square, in this so small space this church has 24 columns: four at the main entrance to the door, six in each collateral chapel, and eight in the main of all..."''.<ref name=SIPA/>
In 1728, by order of Archibishop [[Dom (title)|D.]] Rodrigo de Moura Teles, the beginnings of a reconstruction and remodelling of the Convent of São Francisco's Church is undertaken, with the chapel of São Frutuoso integrated into the Church.<ref name=SIPA/> From this point forward, the Chapel is accessible from the main Church, owing to significant alterations; this changes include, the destruction of the main façade, the modification of the eastern and western arms of the [[Latin cross]]-design; and alterations to the internal columns, including changes to the [[baldachin]]s.<ref name=SIPA/>
It was architect Ernest Korrodi who first promoted the recuperation of the original plan for the chapel (in 1897), publishing a small note entitled ''"Um Monumento Latino-Bizantino em Portugal"'' (''A Latin-Byzantine Monument in Portugal'').<ref name=SIPA/> More than a century would pass, before João de Moura Coutinho e Sousa Lobo would begin to restore the original plan in 1931.<ref name=SIPA/> The architect followed the original hypothesis that the chapel was ordered constructed by [[Fructuosus of Braga]] as his 6th century tomb, following a model/design aesthetic based on the mausoleum [[Mausoleum of Galla Placidia|Galla Placidia]] in [[Ravenna]].<ref name=SIPA/> This redesign was followed by the DGEMN reconstruction of [[cupola]] and roof in 1939, again in 1941, repairs in 1958, that included the reconstruction of the walls, door, plastering of the cupola and several projects around the churchyard. In 1961, the pavement, main arch, reconstruction of the staircase and consolidation of the vaulted ceiling were undertaken, followed by conservation projects in 1966.<ref name=SIPA/> Similar repairs were undertaken in 1970 (repair and cleaning of the roof), in 1973 (checking of the rood, repairs, painting conservancy and arrangement of the area around the chapel), in 1984 (arrangement of the roof and paintings) and in 1987 (new projects evolving conservancy).
==Architecture== The chapel is situated on the eastern lateral façade of the church of the Convent of São Francisco, below the level of the latter. While access to the interior of the chapel is made from the church, its original exterior access was made from through a small enclosed courtyard and gates. East of the chapel are the ruins of the old convent and its dependencies, in addition to the Fountain of Santo António ({{lang-pt|Fonte de Santo António}}) which is further below these buildings. To the southeast, the old granite pavement leads to the Quinta do Lago (''Estate of the Lake'') and the Escola Primária de Real (''Primary School of Real'') to the west.<ref name=SIPA/>
The chapel of São Frutuoso continues to be an enigma, but it is a uniquely rare example of [[Visigoth]]ic structures in Portugal, based on a Greek-cross, which may have followed the design of a Byzantine mausoleum comparable to the [[Mausoleum of Galla Placidia|Galla Placidia]], in [[Ravenna]].<ref name=SIPA/>
The church is laid out in a [[Greek cross]] design, with a rectangular exterior, and semi-circular interior arms (to the north, south and east).<ref name=":0" /> From the exterior, the main volume of the chapel is surmounted by a tower-like cupola and cross, with the roof covered in rounded tiles. The limestone walls are surmounted by edged cornices, preceded by frieses, also in limestone, in the shape of rope, semi-circles, six-pointed rosettas and fleur-de-lis. The collateral façades are decorated with blind arcades, alternating between angular and double rounded-frieses, which are repeated in the tower cupola, and intersected by small round windows. The principal façade, which was the main entrance at one time, is highlighted by a grand arch portico, preceded by staircase. In northern part of the eastern arm of the chapel is an [[arcosolium]], where the mortel remains of Saint Fructuosus was originally entombed, and exposed to the exterior.
===Interior=== The inner masonry walls are defined by round arches, supported by large pillars, above which are large decorated friezes, with triple horseshoe-shaped arches, and a larger central arch. The chapel's arms are crossed in the middle of the wall by a narrow ribbon of limestone. While the interior arms are supported by wooden joists, the interior part of the hemispherical dome is plastered and painted white. The granite floor slabs are inscribed with coat of arms, and preceded from the main church by a staircase to the lower chapel.

'''''Chidatsu''''' (c653) was a priest of the [[Hosso]] School of [[Japanese Buddhism]]. ==Nomenclature and etymology== Chitatsu / Chidatsu (智達) ==Exegesis== ''The [[Soka Gakkai]] Dictionary of Buddhism'' (2002) mentions [[Hsyan-tsang]], [[Tz'u-en]], [[Dosho of Gango-ji]], [[Nara religion|Nara]], [[Gango-ji]], [[Chitsuare]] in reference to elucidating that Chitatsu was:
A priest of the Dharma Characteristics (Hosso) school in Japan. In 658, together with Chitsu, he journeyed to China and studied the doctrine of the Dharma Characteristics school under Hsyan-tsang and his disciple Tz'u-en. They brought the doctrine back with them. Earlier, [[Dōshō]] of [[Gangō-ji]] temple in [[Nara, Nara | Nara]] went to China in 653 and studied under Hsyan-tsang. On his return he spread the Dharma Characteristics teaching at Gango-ji. Thus Chitatsu and Chitsuare regarded together as the second to propagate the doctrine of this school in Japan. After his return, Chitatsu lived at Gango-ji temple and disseminated the Dharma Characteristics doctrine.''The [[Soka Gakkai]] Dictionary of Buddhism'' (2002). ''Chitatsu''. Source: [http://www.sgilibrary.org/search_dict.php?id=302] (accessed: January 7, 2008)

{{Taoism}} '''Chinese Taoist Association''' (CTA ; {{zh|c=中国道教协会}}), founded in April 1957, is the main association of [[Taoism]] in the [[People's Republic of China]]. It is recognized as one of the main religious associations in the People's Republic of China, and is overseen by the [[State Administration for Religious Affairs]]. Dozens of regional and local Taoist associations are included in this overarching group, which is encouraged by the government to be a bridge between Chinese Taoists and the government, to encourage a patriotic merger between Taoism and government initiatives.<ref>[http://english.gov.cn/2007-09/19/content_755854.htm Jia attends China Taoist Association's 50th founding anniversary<!-- Bot generated title -->] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20071009023028/http://english.gov.cn/2007-09/19/content_755854.htm |date=2007-10-09 }}</ref> The group also disseminates information on traditional Taoist topics, including forums and conferences. The association was a major sponsor of the 2007 International Forum on the [[Tao Te Ching]].<ref>[http://www.china.org.cn/english/daodejingforum/207901.htm The Way to Harmony: International Forum on the ''Daodejing'' - china.org.cn<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref> The Chinese Taoist Association advocates the recompensation of losses inflicted on Taoism by the [[Cultural Revolution]]. Taoism was banned for several years in the People's Republic of China during that period.
Taoist practitioners in China are required to register with the Chinese Taoist Association in order to be granted recognition and official protection. The CTA exercises control over religious doctrine and personnel, and dictates the proper interpretation of Taoist doctrine.<ref name=CECC2011>Congressional-Executive Commission on China, [http://www.cecc.gov/pages/annualRpt/annualRpt11/AR2011final.pdf Annual Report 2011] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130213223223/http://www.cecc.gov/pages/annualRpt/annualRpt11/AR2011final.pdf |date=February 13, 2013 }}, Oct 2011.</ref> It also encourages Taoist practitioners to support the Communist Party and the state. For example, a Taoist scripture reading class held by the CTA in November 2010 required participants to ‘‘fervently love the socialist motherland [and] uphold the leadership of the Chinese Communist Party.’’<ref name=CECC2011/> The central government of China has supported and encouraged the Association, along with other official religious groups, in promoting the "harmonious society" initiative of Communist Party General Secretary [[Hu Jintao]].<ref>Xinhua News Agency, [http://www.china.org.cn/english/culture/208446.htm China to Build Harmonious Society with Wisdom of Taoism] 23 April 2007.</ref>

{{infobox | above = Clear (Scientology) | abovestyle = background-color: #99BADD | headerstyle = background-color: #99BADD | label2 = Description | data2 = A condition in which Scientologists say a person is free of the influence of unwanted emotions and memories of trauma | label3 = Early proponents | data3 = [[L. Ron Hubbard]] | label5 = Key texts | data5 = Hubbard's ''[[Dianetics: The Modern Science of Mental Health]]'' (1950) | label6 = Subject | data6 = Religion }} In [[dianetics]] and [[Scientology]], '''Clear''' is one of the major states practitioners strive to reach on their way up the [[Bridge to Total Freedom]]. The state of Clear is reached when a person becomes free of the influence of [[Engram (Dianetics)|engrams]], unwanted emotions or painful traumas not readily available to the conscious mind. Scientologists believe that human beings accumulate anxieties, psychosomatic illnesses, and aberration due to receiving engrams throughout their lives, and that by applying Dianetics, every single person can reach the state of Clear.Goldstein, Laurie. [https://www.nytimes.com/2010/03/07/us/07scientology.html?scp=1&sq=clear+scientology&st=nyt "Defectors Say Church of Scientology Hides Abuse"], ''The New York Times'', March 6, 2010. A Clear is defined by the [[Church of Scientology]] as person who no longer has a "[[reactive mind]]", and is therefore free from the reactive mind's negative effects. A Clear is said to be "at cause over" (that is, in control of) their "mental energy" (their thoughts), and able to think clearly even when faced with the very situations that in earlier times caused them difficulty. The next level of spiritual development is that of an [[Operating Thetan]]. A person who has not reached a state of Clear is called a "pre-clear."Bromley, David G. [https://books.google.com/books?id=-7Ao1LN3XUUC&pg=PA92&dq=%22clear%22+scientology&hl=en&ei=VmQ9TLiGOJP-nAe82ZTeDg&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=1&ved=0CCoQ6AEwAA#v=onepage&q=%22clear%22%20scientology&f=false "Making Sense of Scientology"], in James R. Lewis. ''Scientology''. Oxford University Press, 2009, p. 92. Dianetics states that a person's awareness is influenced by the stimulus-response nature of the reactive mind. Achieving the state of Clear means a person has overcome the reactive mind and is in complete control of their analytical mind. According to Hubbard: "A Clear is a being who no longer has his own reactive mind, and therefore suffers none of the ill effects the reactive mind can cause. The Clear has no engrams which, when restimulated, throw out the correctness of his computations by entering hidden and false data."[http://www.whatisscientology.org/Html/Part14/Chp50/pg1019-a.html What is Scientology web site] Sociologist [[Roy Wallis]] noted, “Being Clear meant being able to do all those things which one could currently not do, and to which one aspired so desperately.”{{cite book |last=Urban |first1=Hugh B. |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=8lgHtauc5R4C&printsec=frontcover&dq=%22church+of+scientology%22&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwiW3tvQ6r3JAhUI0WMKHbYhDmUQ6AEIKzAA#v=onepage&q=%22church%20of%20scientology%22&f=false |title=The Church of Scientology: A History of a New Religion |publisher=Princeton University Press |year=2011 |accessdate=2015-12-17 }} It is estimated that the cost of reaching the Clear state in Scientology is $128,000.[http://altreligion.about.com/od/controversymisconception/a/scientology_cos.htm How Much Does Scientology Cost?] ==The state of Clear== In ''[[Dianetics: The Modern Science of Mental Health|Dianetics]]'', [[L. Ron Hubbard]], founder of [[Scientology]], states that becoming a Clear strengthens a person's native individuality and creativity, and that a Clear is free with his emotions. In ''The State Of Clear,'' a Clear is defined as "a being who no longer has his own reactive mind, and therefore suffers none of the ill effects the reactive mind can cause".[https://web.archive.org/web/20050128013320/http://www.scientology.org/en_US/religion/catechism/pg039.html The State Of Clear: Catechism of Scientology official web site] Hubbard states that merely knowing what the cognition is does not have the effect of realizing it for oneself: {{quote|Now, we've known for a long time that a thetan made up his own bank (reactive mind), but telling him so didn't get him over it. And we've just found out again that telling him so didn't get him over it, too. Even when he's almost Clear. We say, "Hey, you're mocking it up," and he'd say, "Hey, am I mocking it up? Yeah, I am mocking it up." And he'll go Clear — pshew! — and he goes off that bottom step that isn't there, you know? And he's got to go back on and finish it up the way he should. It's got to be his cognition.''Saint Hill Special Briefing Course lecture # 434, 26 July 1966''}} Hubbard described Clears as having "an awareness which can create energy at will, and can handle and control, erase or re-create an analytical or reactive mind". Hubbard claimed that Clears have complete memories and know why events in their lives have happened, which leaves them free to pursue their goals without hindrances (the "[[reactive mind]]") emanating from past experiences. Religious scholar Pat Cook compared being "Clear" to the concept of [[Nirvana (Buddhism)|nirvana]] in Zen Buddhism: like nirvana in Buddhism, Clear is a state of being that is highly desired and respected in Scientology.{{cite journal |title=Scientology and Dianetics |journal=[[The Journal of Education]] |year=1971 |last=Cook |first=Pat |volume=153 |issue=4 |pages=58–61 |jstor=42773008 }} The Clear state is said to be achieved through the Scientology practice of [[auditing (Scientology)|auditing]]. A person undergoing auditing is called a "pre-clear", often abbreviated to "PC", in [[Scientology terminology]]. The Church of Scientology claims that if all individuals in the world were “Clear”, the world would be “free of drugs, war, pollution, crime, mental illness and other ills.”{{cite book|last1=Newport|first1=John P.|title=The New Age Movement and the Biblical Worldview: Conflict and Dialogue|date=1998|publisher=Wm. B. Eerdmans Publishing|isbn=9780802844309}} ==Steps after Clear== After attaining the state of Clear, a person may go on to study the [[Operating Thetan]] levels, which are described in Scientology materials as states where the ability to operate outside the body via "exteriorization" becomes commonplace. Beyond that comes "Cleared Theta Clear", which Hubbard describes this way:
A thetan who is completely rehabilitated and can do everything a thetan should do, such as move [[MEST (Scientology)|MEST [matter, energy, space, and time]]] and control others from a distance, or create his own universe; a person who is able to create his own universe or, living in the MEST universe is able to create illusions perceivable by others at will, to handle MEST universe objects without mechanical means and to have and feel no need of bodies or even the MEST universe to keep himself and his friends interested in existence.Hubbard, ''Scientology 8-8008'', p. 114 (1st ed.), p. 151 (1990 ed.)
==Early Clears== There are several conflicting accounts of who first attained the state of Clear, and under what circumstances. In August 1950, amidst the success of ''[[Dianetics: The Modern Science of Mental Health|Dianetics]]'', Hubbard held a demonstration in Los Angeles' [[Shrine Auditorium]] where he presented a young woman called Sonya Bianca (a pseudonym) to a large audience including many reporters and photographers as "the world's first Clear." However, despite Hubbard's claim that she had "full and perfect recall of every moment of her life", Bianca proved unable to answer questions from the audience testing her memory and analytical abilities, including the question of the color of Hubbard's tie. Hubbard explained Bianca's failure to display her promised powers of recall to the audience by saying that he had used the word "now" in calling her to the stage, and thus inadvertently froze her in "present time," which blocked her abilities.{{cite book|first=Russell|last=Miller|title=Bare-Faced Messiah: The True Story of L. Ron Hubbard|year=1987|isbn=0-8050-0654-0}} Later, in the late 1950s, Hubbard would claim that several people had reached the state of Clear by the time he presented Bianca as the world's first; these others, Hubbard said, he had successfully cleared in the late 1940s while working ''incognito'' in Hollywood posing as a [[swami]].{{cite speech| first=L. Ron| last=Hubbard| title=The Story of Dianetics and Scientology, Lecture 18| date=October 1958| quote="by 1947, I had achieved clearing."}} In 1966, Hubbard declared South African Scientologist John McMaster to be the first true Clear.{{cite journal|first=Alan|last=Levy|title=Scientology|journal=Life|date=1968-11-15}}{{cite journal|first=Wendy|last=Michener|title=Is This the Happiest Man in the World?|journal=Maclean's|date=1966-08-22}} McMaster had joined Scientology around 1962, having experienced relief of chronic stomach pain after his first auditing session. He became a leading public spokesman for Scientology and later a member of the [[Sea Org]]. He left in November 1969, expressing continuing belief in the Scientology [[Scientology beliefs and practices|Tech]], but disapproval of the way Scientology was managed.{{cite book|first=Jon|last=Atack|title=A Piece of Blue Sky: Scientology, Dianetics and L. Ron Hubbard Exposed|year=1990|isbn=0-8184-0499-X}} ==See also== {{Portal|Scientology}} *''[[Going Clear (disambiguation)]]'' ==References== {{Reflist}} ==Further reading== {{Refbegin}} *L. Ron Hubbard, ''Dianetics: The Modern Science Of Mental Health'', 1950 *L. Ron Hubbard, ''The Classification Chart and Auditing'', Saint Hill Special Briefing Course lecture 434, 26 July 1966 *L. Ron Hubbard, ''Dianetic Clear'', HCO Bulletin 24 SeptemberRC 78 Issue III, Revised 18 Dec 88 * [http://www.scientology.org/en_US/religion/catechism/pg039.html Scientology FAQs: The state of Clear] * [https://web.archive.org/web/20070625174407/http://www.essentialdianetics.org/page13.htm EssentialDianetics.org: understanding the mind "The Clear"] * [http://www.neweradianetics.org.uk/page05.htm New Era Dianetics: “The state of Clear”] {{Refend}} {{Scientology}} [[Category:Scientology beliefs and practices]] [[fr:Scientologie#État « Clair »]]

{{for|the Canadian football player|Dick Gregory (Canadian football)}} {{Use mdy dates|date=August 2018}} {{Infobox comedian | name = Dick Gregory | image = Dick Gregory 2015.jpg | caption = Gregory in 2015 | pseudonym = | birth_name = Richard Claxton Gregory | birth_date = {{Birth date|1932|10|12}} | birth_place = [[St. Louis]], [[Missouri]], U.S. | death_date = {{Death date and age|2017|08|19|1932|10|12}} | death_place = [[Washington, D.C.]], U.S. | medium = Civil rights activist, [[stand-up comedy]], film, books, critic | nationality = American | active = 1954–2017 | subject = American [[Civil and political rights|civil rights]], [[Politics of the United States|politics]], [[Culture of the United States|culture]], [[African-American culture]], racism, race relations, [[vegetarianism]], healthy diet | influences = | influenced = | spouse = {{marriage|Lillian Smith
|1959}} | children = 10 | notable_work = ''In Living Black and White ''
''[[Nigger: An Autobiography by Dick Gregory]]'' with Robert Lipsyte
''Write Me In!'' ''[[Fire, The Dick Gregory Story: A Biography for Young Adults]]'' by Shelia P. Moses | signature = | website = [http://www.dickgregory.com/ www.dickgregory.com] | footnotes = }} '''Richard Claxton Gregory''' (October 12, 1932 – August 19, 2017) was an American comedian, [[civil rights movement|civil rights]] activist, social critic, writer, conspiracy theorist,[http://www.npr.org/templates/story/story.php?storyId=4749316 "Dick Gregory's Role as Michael Jackson's Adviser"], NPR, July 12, 2005. entrepreneur,{{cite web|last=Wiley|first=Ed|url=http://www.nbcnews.com/id/14789644/|title=The 9/11 conspiracy: Rubbish or reality? – US news – Life – Race & ethnicity|publisher=MSNBC|date=November 9, 2006|access-date=April 4, 2012|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140319012825/http://www.nbcnews.com/id/14789644/|archivedate=March 19, 2014}}[https://www.npr.org/templates/story/story.php?storyId=4749316 "Dick Gregory's Role as Michael Jackson's Adviser"], NPR, July 12, 2005. and occasional actor. During the turbulent 1960s, Gregory became a pioneer in stand-up comedy for his "no-holds-barred" sets, in which he mocked bigotry and [[Racism in the United States|racism]]. He performed primarily to black audiences at [[Racial segregation|segregated]] clubs until 1961, when he became the first black comedian to successfully cross over to white audiences, appearing on television and putting out comedy record albums.{{cite news|last1=Porter|first1=Tom|title=Here's all you need to know about pioneering comedian and civil rights activist Dick Gregory, who has died aged 84|url=http://www.newsweek.com/dick-gregory-heres-what-you-need-know-about-pioneering-comedian-and-civil-652431|accessdate=August 20, 2017|work=Newsweek|date=August 20, 2017|language=en}} Gregory was at the forefront of political activism in the 1960s, when he protested the Vietnam War and [[Racism in the United States#African Americans|racial injustice]]. He was arrested multiple times and went on many hunger strikes.''Democracy Now'', Amy Goodman, August 21, 2017. He later became a speaker and author, primarily promoting spirituality. Gregory died of heart failure at a Washington, D.C., hospital at age 84 in August 2017. == Early life == Gregory was born in [[St. Louis, Missouri]], the son of Lucille, a housemaid, and Presley Gregory.[http://www.encyclopedia.com/people/history/historians-miscellaneous-biographies/dick-gregory "Dick Gregory"], Contemporary Black Biography. ''Encyclopedia.com''. When he was nine years old, he was the victim of a racist attack for touching a white woman's leg while shining her shoes.{{cite news|author=|title=Obituary: Richard "Dick" Gregory died on August 19th|url=https://www.economist.com/news/obituary/21728607-american-comedian-dietician-and-civil-rights-campaigner-was-84-obituary-richard-dick|work=[[The Economist]]|date=September 7, 2017}} At [[Sumner High School (St. Louis)|Sumner High School]], he was aided by teachers, among them Warren St. James; he also excelled at running. Gregory earned a track scholarship to [[Southern Illinois University Carbondale|Southern Illinois University]] (SIU),[http://www.aeiSpeakers.com/speakerbio.php?SpeakerID=461 Dick Gregory], AEI Speakers Bureau. Accessed December 11, 2007. "A track star at Sumner High School, Gregory earned an athletic scholarship in 1951 to Southern Illinois University at Carbondale and became the first member of his family to attend college." where he set school records as a half-miler and miler.{{cite magazine|last1=Fields-White|first1=Monée|title=Comedian and Civil Rights Activist Dick Gregory Dead at 84|url=http://www.theroot.com/comedian-and-civil-rights-activist-dick-gregory-dead-at-1797977671|magazine=[[The Root (magazine)|The Root]]|accessdate=August 20, 2017|date=August 19, 2017}} He was a member of [[Alpha Phi Alpha]] fraternity. In 1954, his college career was interrupted for two years when he was drafted into the [[United States Army]]. At the urging of his commanding officer, who had taken notice of his penchant for joking, Gregory got his start in comedy in the Army, where he entered and won several talent shows. In 1956, Gregory briefly returned to SIU after his discharge, but dropped out because he felt that the university "didn't want me to study, they wanted me to run."{{cite book|last1=Otfinoski|first1=Steven|title=African Americans in the Performing Arts|date=2014|publisher=Infobase Publishing|isbn=1438107765|page=88}} In the hopes of becoming a professional comedian, Gregory moved to [[Chicago, Illinois]], where he became part of a new generation of black comedians that included [[Nipsey Russell]], [[Bill Cosby]], and [[Godfrey Cambridge]], all of whom broke with the minstrel tradition that presented stereotypical black characters. Gregory drew on current events, especially racial issues, for much of his material: "Segregation is not all bad. Have you ever heard of a collision where the people in the back of the bus got hurt?" == Career == {{external media | width = 210px | align = right |headerimage = [[File:2014 Ferguson and Beyond Rally 31.jpg|210px]] | video1 =[https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=p0obdh1wvGs Dick Gregory: Advice to Young African Americans], National Visionary Leadership Project | video2 =[https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=OfAzq4Q_KZs Dick Gregory: The Civil Rights Movement – Part 1], National Visionary Leadership Project | access-date =December 12, 2014 | video3 = [https://www.c-span.org/video/?162903-1/callus-soul-memoir ''Booknotes'' interview with Gregory on ''Callus on My Soul: A Memoir'', March 4, 2001], [[C-SPAN]]}} Gregory began his career as a comedian while serving in the military in the mid-1950s. He served in the Army for a year and a half at [[Fort Hood]] in Texas, [[Fort Lee (Virginia)|Fort Lee]] in Virginia, and Fort Smith in Arkansas. He was drafted in 1954 while attending Southern Illinois University. After being discharged in 1956, he returned to the university but did not receive a degree. He moved to Chicago with a desire to perform comedy professionally.{{cite web|url=http://www.dickgregory.com/about_dick_gregory.html|title=About – Dick Gregory Global Watch|author=Flash|work=dickgregory.com|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070617034501/http://www.dickgregory.com/about_dick_gregory.html|archivedate=June 17, 2007}} In 1958, Gregory opened the Apex Club nightclub in Illinois. The club failed and landed Gregory in financial hardship. In 1959, Gregory landed a job as master of ceremonies at the Roberts Show Club.[http://www.visionaryproject.org/gregorydick/ "Dick Gregory – National Visionary"], National Visionary Leadership Project. While working for the [[United States Postal Service]] during the daytime, Gregory performed as a comedian in small, primarily black-patronized [[nightclub]]s. He was one of the first black comedians to gain widespread acclaim while performing for white audiences. In an interview with ''[[HuffPost|The Huffington Post]]'', Gregory described the history of black comics as limited: "Blacks could sing and dance in the white night clubs but weren't allowed to stand flat-footed and talk to white folks, which is what a comic does."{{cite news|last1=Saunders|first1=Lonna|title=Dick Gregory: "What I'm Running From" Bryn Mawr College Feb. 28|url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/lonna-saunders/dick-gregory_b_2756800.html|accessdate=August 24, 2017|publisher=Huffington Post|date=April 29, 2013}} In 1961, Gregory was working at the black-owned Roberts Show Bar in Chicago when he was spotted by [[Hugh Hefner]]. Gregory was performing the following material before a largely white audience: {{quote|Good evening, ladies and gentlemen. I understand there are a good many Southerners in the room tonight. I know the South very well. I spent twenty years there one night. Last time I was down South I walked into this restaurant and this white waitress came up to me and said, "We don't serve colored people here." I said, "That's all right. I don't eat colored people. Bring me a whole fried chicken." Then these three white boys came up to me and said, "Boy, we're giving you fair warning. Anything you do to that chicken, we're gonna do to you." So I put down my knife and fork, I picked up that chicken and I kissed it. Then I said, "Line up, boys!"[bit.ly/LooseWeightFast1]{{ Title=How to lose Weight Fast |date=November 2016|bot=InternetArchiveBot|fix-attempted=yes}}}} Gregory attributed the launch of his career to Hefner. Based on his performance at Roberts Show Bar, Hefner hired Gregory to work at the Chicago [[Playboy|Playboy Club]] as a replacement for comedian "Professor" [[Irwin Corey]].{{cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2010/02/21/nyregion/21comicswe.html|title=A Bit Slower, but Still Throwing Lethal Punch Lines|first=Phillip|last=Lutz|work=[[The New York Times]]|date=February 19, 2010}} Gregory made his first television appearance on the late night show ''[[Tonight Starring Jack Paar]]''.{{cite web|title=Dick Gregory's Appearance on Arsenio PT. 2|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=KXUBS-sieOg|website=YouTube|access-date=November 11, 2016|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20161111200730/https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=KXUBS-sieOg|archivedate=November 11, 2016|date=May 16, 2014}} He soon began appearing nationally and on television. Early in his career, Gregory was offered an engagement on ''Tonight Starring Jack Paar''. [[Jack Paar|Paar's]] show was known for helping propel entertainers to the next level of their careers. At the time, black comics did perform on the show, but after their performances, they were never asked to stay and sit on the famous couch and talk with the host.{{cite web|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2017/08/19/arts/dick-gregory-dies-at-84.html|title=Dick Gregory, 84, Dies; Found Humor in the Civil Rights Struggle|last=Haberman|first=Clyde|date=August 19, 2017|publisher=''New York Times''|accessdate=August 25, 2017}} Dick Gregory declined several invitations from Jack Paar to perform on the show. Paar finally called him to find out why he refused to perform on his show. In order to have Gregory perform, the producers eventually agreed to allow him to stay after his performance and talk with the host on air. This was a first in the show's history. Gregory's interview on ''Tonight Starring Jack Paar'' spurred conversations across America. Gregory's comedy occasioned controversy in some conservative white circles. The administration of the University of Tennessee, for instance, branded Gregory an "extreme racist"Ernest Freeberg, [http://www.knoxnews.com/story/opinion/columnists/2017/09/07/inviting-controversy-when-tennessee-students-demanded-free-speech-rights-half-century-ago/625129001/ "Inviting Controversy: When Tennessee Students Demanded Free Speech Rights, a Half Century Ago"], ''Knoxville News Sentinel'', September 7, 2017. whose "appearance would be an outrage and an insult to many citizens of this state",G. Michel, ''Struggle for a Better South: The Southern Student Organization Committee, 1964-1969'' (Springer 2004), p.183. and revoked his invitation by students to speak on campus. The students sued, with noted litigator [[William Kunstler]] as their counsel, and in ''Smith v. University of Tennessee'', 300 F. Supp. 777 (E.D. Tenn. 1969), won an order from the court that the University's policy was "too broad and vague". The University of Tennessee then implemented an "open speaker" system, and Gregory subsequently performed in April 1970. == Post-standup career == Gregory was number 82 on [[Comedy Central]]'s list of the ''100 Greatest Stand-ups'' of all time and had his own star on the [[St. Louis Walk of Fame]].{{cite web|url=http://www.stlouiswalkoffame.org/inductees/?view=achievement|title=St. Louis Walk of Fame Inductees|last=St. Louis Walk of Fame|publisher=|access-date=April 25, 2013}} He was a co-host with radio personality [[Cathy Hughes]], and was a frequent morning guest, on WOL 1450 AM talk radio's "The Power", the flagship station of Hughes' Radio One.{{cite news|first=Wil|last=Haywood|url=http://www.commondreams.org/views/2000/08/24/pain-and-passion-dick-gregory|title=The Pain and Passion of Dick Gregory|newspaper=[[Boston Globe]]|date=August 24, 2000|publisher=[[CommonDreams]]|accessdate=August 20, 2017}} He also appeared regularly on the nationally syndicated ''[[Imus in the Morning]]'' program.{{cite web|last1=Hinckley|first1=David|title=How Dick Gregory Took Himself Off the Main Stage, and Why|url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/entry/how-dick-gregory-took-himself-off-the-main-stage-and_us_599922e7e4b03b5e472cf06c|website=[[Huffington Post]]|accessdate=August 20, 2017|date=August 20, 2017}} Gregory appeared as "Mr. Sun" on the television show ''[[Wonder Showzen]]'' (the third episode, entitled "Ocean", aired in 2005). As Chauncey, a puppet character, imbibes a [[hallucinogen]]ic substance, Mr. Sun warns, "Don't get hooked on imagination, Chauncey. It can lead to terrible, horrible things." Gregory also provided guest commentary on the ''Wonder Showzen'' Season One DVD.{{cite web|last1=Drucker|first1=Michael|title=Wonder Showzen: Season One|url=http://www.ign.com/articles/2006/03/16/wonder-showzen-season-one?page=2|website=[[IGN]]|accessdate=August 20, 2017|date=March 15, 2006}} Large segments of his commentary were intentionally bleeped out, including the names of several dairy companies, as he made potentially defamatory remarks concerning ill effects that the consumption of [[Milk|cow milk]] has on human beings. Gregory attended and spoke at the funeral of [[James Brown]] on December 30, 2006, in [[Augusta, Georgia]].{{cite news|last1=Nguyen|first1=Daisy|title=Comedian, civil rights activist Dick Gregory dies|url=https://www.pbs.org/newshour/rundown/comedian-civil-rights-activist-dick-gregory-dies/|accessdate=August 20, 2017|agency=Associated Press|newspaper=[[PBS]]|date=August 20, 2017}} Gregory was an occasional guest on the Mark Thompson's ''Make It Plain'' Sirius Channel 146 Radio Show from 3pm to 6pm PST.{{cite book|last1=Haggins|first1=Bambi|title=Laughing Mad: The Black Comic Persona in Post-soul America|date=2007|publisher=[[Rutgers University Press]]|isbn=9780813539850|page=22|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=REBY5ldTaAAC&lpg=PA22&ots=c3SXt5CDVO&dq=dick-gregory%20%22make%20it%20plain%22&pg=PA22#v=onepage&q=dick-gregory%20%22make%20it%20plain%22&f=false}} Gregory appeared on [[Alex Jones (radio host)|''The Alex Jones Show'']] on September 14, 2010, March 19, 2012, and April 1, 2014.{{cite web|title=Civil Rights Icon Dick Gregory: The Social Engineers are Here to Divide and Conquer Us 1/4|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=ujo6CQKQNrI|website=The Alex Jones Channel|via=YouTube|date=September 14, 2010|accessdate=August 20, 2017}}{{cite web|title=Obama: The Globalist Ultimate Puppet with Civil Rights Icon Dick Gregory|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=GVoXIT49qKs|website=The Alex Jones Channel|via=YouTube|date=March 19, 2012|accessdate=August 20, 2017}}{{cite web|title=Secret Of Malaysia Flight 370: "Brain-Heist"|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=6XBEKS3bWzc|website=The Alex Jones Channel|via=YouTube|accessdate=August 20, 2017|date=April 1, 2014}} Gregory gave the keynote address for Black History Month at [[Bryn Mawr College]] on February 28, 2013.{{cite news|url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/lonna-saunders/dick-gregory_b_2756800.html|work=[[HuffPost|The Huffington Post]]|first=Lonna|last=Saunders|title=Dick Gregory: "What I'm Running From" Bryn Mawr College Feb. 28|date=February 27, 2013}} His take-away message to the students was to never accept injustice. {{quote|Once I accept injustice, I become injustice. For example, paper mills give off a terrible stench. But the people who work there don't smell it. Remember, Dr. King was assassinated when he went to work for [[Memphis sanitation strike|garbage collectors]]. To help them as workers to enforce their rights. They couldn't smell the stench of the garbage all around them anymore. They were used to it. They would eat their lunch out of a brown bag sitting on the garbage truck. One day, a worker was sitting inside the back of the truck on top of the garbage, and got crushed to death because no one knew he was there.}} Even as late as 2013, Gregory continued to be a ringing voice of the [[Black Power|black power]] movement. Towards the end of his life, he was featured in a Fantagraphics book by Pat Thomas entitled ''Listen, Whitey: The Sights and Sounds of Black Power 1965–1975'', which uses the political recordings of the Civil Rights era to highlight sociopolitical meanings throughout the movement.[http://lightintheattic.net/releases/685-listen-whitey-the-sounds-of-black-power-1967-1974 "Listen, Whitey! The Sounds of Black Power 1967–1974"], Light in the Attic Records. Gregory is known for comedic performances that not only made people laugh, but mocked [[The Establishment|the establishment]]. According to Thomas, Gregory's monologues reflect a time when entertainment needed to be political to be relevant, which is why he included his standup in the collection. Gregory is featured along with the likes of [[Huey P. Newton]], [[Jesse Jackson]], [[Martin Luther King Jr.]], Langston Hughes and Bill Cosby.{{cite news|url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/tom-semioli/listen-to-this-book-the-s_b_4173930.html|work=[[HuffPost|The Huffington Post]]|first=Tom|last=Semioli|title=Listen to This Book: The Sights and Sounds of Black Power 1965–1975|date=October 30, 2013}} [[Joe Morton]] played Dick Gregory in 2016 in the play ''Turn Me Loose'' at the [[Westside Theatre]] in Manhattan.[http://www.newyorktheatreguide.com/reviews/turnmeloose16.htm "Off-Broadway Theatre Review: ''Turn Me Loose''"] by Tulis McCall, ''New York Theatre Guide'', May 31, 2016 == Personal life == Gregory met his future wife Lillian Gregory{{cite web|last=Yes|first=The|url=https://www.flickr.com/photos/the_yes_we_cantv/5756042507/|title=Journalist Lillian Smith with her mentor Human Rights Activist Dick Gregory. | Flickr – Photo Sharing!|publisher=Flickr|date=June 19, 2011|access-date=April 4, 2012}} at an African-American club; they married in 1959. They had 11 children (including one son, Richard Jr., who died two months after birth): Michele, Lynne, Pamela, Paula, Stephanie (also known as Xenobia), Gregory, Christian, Miss, Ayanna, and Yohance. He was criticized for being an absent father. In a 2000 interview with ''The Boston Globe'', Gregory was quoted as saying, "People ask me about being a father and not being there. I say, 'Jack the Ripper had a father. Hitler had a father. Don't talk to me about family.'" ==Activism== ===Political activism=== [[File:Dick Gregory.jpg|thumb|right|Gregory in 1964]] ==== Civil rights movement ==== [[File:Dick Gregory Tallahassee.jpg|thumb|Gregory in 1969 in Tallahassee]] Gregory was active in the [[civil rights movement]]. On October 7, 1963, he came to [[Selma, Alabama]], and spoke for two hours on a public platform two days before the voter registration drive known as "Freedom Day" (October 7, 1963).[[Howard Zinn]], ''You Can't Be Neutral on a Moving Train''. Beacon Press, 1994; rev. ed. 2002, p. 58. In 1964, Gregory became more involved in civil rights activities, activism against the [[Vietnam War]], economic reform, and anti-drug issues. As a part of his activism, he went on several [[hunger strike]]s and campaigns in America and overseas. In the early 1970s, he was banned from Australia, where government officials feared he would "...stir up demonstrations against the Vietnam war."{{cite web|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?nid=1696&dat=19710910&id=0LsdAAAAIBAJ&sjid=ikYEAAAAIBAJ&pg=7222,2658601|last= Hart |first=Jeffrey |title=Evonne Goolagong Plays Tennis in South Africa| date=September 10, 1971|work=[[New York Daily News]]}} In 1964, Gregory played a role in the search for three [[Murders of Chaney, Goodman, and Schwerner|missing civil rights workers]], [[James Chaney]], [[Andrew Goodman]], and [[Michael Schwerner]], who vanished in [[Philadelphia, Mississippi]]. After Gregory and members of [[Congress of Racial Equality|CORE]] met with [[Neshoba County, Mississippi|Neshoba County]] Sheriff [[Lawrence A. Rainey]], Gregory became convinced that the Sheriff's office was complicit. With cash provided by [[Hugh Hefner]], Gregory announced a $25,000 reward for information. The [[FBI]], which had been criticized for inaction, eventually followed suit with its own reward, and the rewards worked. The bodies of the three men were found by the FBI 44 days after they disappeared.{{cite news|title=How Dick Gregory Forced the FBI to Find the Bodies of Three Civil Rights Workers Slain in Mississippi|url=http://readersupportednews.org/opinion2/277-75/45776-how-dick-gregory-forced-the-fbi-to-find-the-bodies-of-three-civil-rights-workers-slain-in-mississippi|date=September 14, 2017|accessdate=September 17, 2017|agency=http://readersupportednews.org/}} At a civil rights rally marking the 40th anniversary of the [[Voting Rights Act of 1965]], Gregory criticized the United States, calling it "the most dishonest, ungodly, unspiritual nation that ever existed in the history of the planet. As we talk now, America is 5 percent of the world's population and consumes 96 percent of the world's hard drugs".{{cite web|url=http://www.newsMax.com/archives/ic/2005/8/8/102152.shtml|title=Newsmax.com – Breaking news from around the globe: U.S. news, politics, world, health, finance, video, science, technology, live news stream|author=Newsmax|work=newsmax.com|archive-url=https://archive.is/20120909184044/http://www.newsmax.com/archives/ic/2005/8/8/102152.shtml|archive-date=September 9, 2012|dead-url=yes}} ===== Assassination of Martin Luther King, Jr. ===== Gregory and Mark Lane conducted landmark research into the [[Assassination of Martin Luther King Jr.|assassination of Dr. Martin Luther King Jr.]], helping move the U.S. House Select Assassinations Committee to investigate the murder, along with [[Assassination of John F. Kennedy|that of John F. Kennedy]]. Lane was the author of conspiracy theory books such as ''[[Rush to Judgment]]''. The pair wrote the King conspiracy book ''Code Name Zorro'', which postulated that convicted assassin [[James Earl Ray]] did not act alone. Gregory also argued that the moon landing was faked and the commonly accepted account of the 9/11 attacks is incorrect, among other conspiracy theories. ==== Native American rights ==== In 1966, Gregory and his wife were arrested for illegal net fishing along side of the [[Nisqually people|Nisqually]] people in Washington state in a protest [[fish-in]]. The tribe was protesting against the state laws that ban forms of fishing other than [[Hook and line fishing|hook-and-line]] because it barred their rights guaranteed to them through a federal treaty that allowed them to fish in their traditional ways.{{Cite book|title=The Native North American Almanac|last=Champagne|first=Duane|publisher=Gale Group|year=2001|isbn=0787616559|location=Farmington Hills, MI|pages=}} He was later released from jail in [[Olympia, Washington]] after six weeks of [[fasting]] to call attention to the violation of [[Native American treaties]] by the United States government. ==== Political career ==== Gregory began his political career by running against [[Richard J. Daley]] for Mayor of Chicago in 1967. Though he did not win, this would not prove to be the end of his participation in electoral politics.{{cite news|title=Dick Gregory, pioneering US comedian and activist, dies aged 84|url=https://www.theguardian.com/us-news/2017/aug/20/dick-gregory-pioneering-us-comedian-and-activist-dies-aged-84|accessdate=August 20, 2017|agency=[[Associated Press]]|newspaper=[[The Guardian]]|date=August 19, 2017}} Gregory ran for President of the United States in 1968 as a [[write-in candidate]] of the Freedom and Peace Party, which had broken off from the [[Peace and Freedom Party]]. He garnered 47,097 votes, including one from [[Hunter S. Thompson]],{{Cite book|last=Thompson|first=Hunter S.|authorlink=Hunter S. Thompson|title=The Great Shark Hunt|series=Gonzo Papers|volume=1|origyear=1974|year=1979|publisher=[[Simon & Schuster]]|location=New York|isbn=0-7432-5045-1|page=20|chapter=|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=VHxgGvF9ugAC&pg=PA20&dq#PPA19,M1|quote=Hubert Humphrey lost that election by a handful of votes – mine among them – and if I had it to do again I would still vote for Dick Gregory.|postscript=}} with fellow activist [[Mark Lane (author)|Mark Lane]] as his running mate in some states. His running mate in New Jersey was Dr. David Frost of Plainfield, a biologist, Rutgers professor, and Chairman of NJ SANE (Committee for a Sane Nuclear Policy).Famed pediatrician Dr. [[Benjamin Spock]] was the running mate in Virginia{{cite news|title=People's Party Nominates Dr. Spock For President|author=|newspaper=Spartanburg Herald-Journal|date=November 29, 1971|pages=B5|url=|access-date=}} and Pennsylvania{{cite news|title=Spock, Gregory to Be on Ballot|author=|newspaper=Cape Girardeau Southeast Missourian|date=March 6, 1968|page=10|url=|access-date=}} garnering more than the party he had left.{{cite web|url=http://www.ourcampaigns.com/RaceDetail.html?RaceID=1940|title=Our Campaigns - US President National Vote Race - Nov 05, 1968|work=ourcampaigns.com}} The Freedom and Peace Party also ran other candidates, including Beulah Sanders for [[New York State Senate]] and Flora Brown for [[New York State Assembly]].{{cite web|url=http://www.ourCampaigns.com/PartyDetail.html?PartyID=1597|title=Our Campaigns – Political Party – Freedom & Peace (FPP)|work=ourcampaigns.com}} His efforts landed him on the [[master list of Nixon's political opponents]]. Gregory then wrote the book ''Write Me In'' about his presidential campaign. One anecdote in the book relates the story of a publicity stunt that came out of [[Operation Breadbasket]] in Chicago. The campaign had printed dollar bills with Gregory's image on them, some of which made it into circulation, causing considerable problems, but priceless publicity. The majority of these bills were quickly seized by the federal government. A large contributing factor to the seizure came from the bills resembling authentic United States currency enough that they worked in many dollar-cashing machines of the time. Gregory avoided being charged with a federal crime, later joking that the bills could not really be considered United States currency, because "everyone knows a black man will never be on a U.S. bill."{{cite news|last1=Evans|first1=Bradford|title=8 Memorable Political Campaigns by Comedians|url=http://splitsider.com/2011/08/8-memorable-political-campaigns-by-comedians/|accessdate=August 24, 2017|publisher=Splitsider|date=August 31, 2011}} ==== Warren Commission ==== Shortly after this time, Gregory became an outspoken critic of the [[John F. Kennedy assassination conspiracy theories|findings]] of the [[Warren Commission]] concerning the [[assassination of John F. Kennedy]] by [[Lee Harvey Oswald]]. On March 6, 1975, Gregory and assassination researcher [[Robert J. Groden]] appeared on [[Geraldo Rivera]]'s late night ABC talk show ''Goodnight America''. An important historical event happened that night when the famous [[Zapruder film]] of JFK's assassination was shown to the public on TV for the first time.{{YouTube|4DwKK4rkeEM|Zapruder film on Good Night America – 3/6/75 Robert Groden and Dick Gregory}}. The public's response and outrage to its showing led to the forming of the Hart-Schweiker investigation, which contributed to the [[Church Committee]] Investigation on Intelligence Activities by the United States, which resulted in the [[United States House Select Committee on Assassinations]] investigation. ==== Feminism ==== Gregory was an outspoken feminist, and in 1978 joined [[Gloria Steinem]], [[Betty Friedan]], [[Bella Abzug]], [[Margaret Heckler]], [[Barbara Mikulski]], and other suffragists to lead the ''National ERA March for Ratification and Extension'', a march down [[Pennsylvania Avenue]] to the [[United States Capitol]] of over 100,000 on [[Women's Equality Day]] (August 26), 1978, to demonstrate for a ratification deadline extension for the proposed [[Equal Rights Amendment]] to the [[United States Constitution]], and for the ratification of the ERA.{{cite magazine|last1=Muhammad|first1=Latifah|title=Dick Gregory, Comedic Legend And Civil Rights Activist, Dead At 84|url=https://www.vibe.com/2017/08/dick-gregory-comedian-activist-dead-at-84/|accessdate=August 20, 2017|magazine=[[Vibe (magazine)|Vibe]]|date=August 19, 2017}} The march was ultimately successful in extending the deadline to June 30, 1982, and Gregory joined other activists to the Senate for celebration and victory speeches by pro-ERA Senators, Members of Congress, and activists. The ERA narrowly failed to be ratified by the extended ratification date. ==== Anti-Apartheid ==== On July 21, 1979, Gregory appeared at the [[Amandla Festival]] where [[Bob Marley]], [[Patti LaBelle]], and [[Eddie Palmieri]], amongst others, performed.{{cite web|last1=Eaton|first1=Perry|title=Long before Boston Calling, there was the Amandla Festival|url=https://www.boston.com/culture/music/2017/05/24/long-before-boston-calling-amandla-festival-brought-bob-marley-and-social-justice-to-harvard|website=[[Boston.com]]|accessdate=August 20, 2017|date=May 24, 2017}} Gregory gave a speech before Marley's performance, blaming President [[Jimmy Carter|Carter]], and showing his support for the international [[Anti-Apartheid Movement]]. ==== US Embassy Hostage Crisis in Iran ==== Gregory was an outspoken activist during the [[Iran hostage crisis|US Embassy Hostage Crisis in Iran]]. In 1980, he traveled to [[Tehran]] to attempt to negotiate the hostages' release and engaged in a public hunger strike there, weighing less than 100 pounds (45 kg) when he returned to the United States.{{cite news|url=http://www.latimes.com/local/obituaries/la-me-dick-gregory-20170819-story.html|title=Dick Gregory, who rose from poverty to become a groundbreaking comedian and civil rights activist, dies at 84|author=Dennis McLellahn|newspaper=[[Los Angeles Times]]|access-date=August 19, 2017|date=August 19, 2017}} ==== Martin Luther King, Jr. ==== [[File:WIKI - Dick Gregory 1995.jpg|thumb|right|In October 1995 Gregory returned to the Broadway stage to perform comedy once again after a 23-year absence.]] Gregory and Mark Lane conducted landmark research into the [[Assassination of Martin Luther King Jr.|assassination of Dr. Martin Luther King Jr.]], helping move the U.S. House Select Assassinations Committee to investigate the murder, along with [[Assassination of John F. Kennedy|that of John F. Kennedy]]. Lane was the author of conspiracy theory books such as ''[[Rush to Judgment]]''. The pair wrote the King conspiracy book ''Code Name Zorro'', which postulated that convicted assassin [[James Earl Ray]] did not act alone. Gregory also argued that the moon landing was faked and the commonly accepted account of the 9/11 attacks is incorrect, among other conspiracy theories. In 1998, Gregory spoke at the celebration of the birthday of Dr Martin Luther King Jr., with President [[Bill Clinton]] in attendance. Not long after, the President told Gregory's long-time friend and public relations consultant [[Steve Jaffe]], "I love Dick Gregory; he is one of the funniest people on the planet." They spoke of how Gregory had made a comment on Dr. King's birthday that broke everyone into laughter, when he noted that the President made Speaker [[Newt Gingrich]] ride "in the back of the plane," on an Air Force One trip overseas.{{cite news|title=Clinton leads tribute to King|url=http://edition.cnn.com/US/9601/mlk/clinton/|accessdate=August 20, 2017|newspaper=[[CNN]]|date=January 15, 1996}} ==== Health ==== Gregory was diagnosed with [[lymphoma]] in late 1999. He said he was treating the cancer with herbs, vitamins, and exercise, which he believed kept the cancer in remission.{{cite journal|url=http://findArticles.com/p/articles/mi_m1355/is_26_97/ai_62685512|title=Dick Gregory Talks About His Fight With Cancer|work=[[Jet (magazine)|Jet]]|date=June 2000}} Beginning in the mid-1980s, Gregory was a figure in the [[health food]] industry by advocating for a raw fruit and vegetable diet. He wrote the introduction to Viktoras Kulvinskas' book ''Survival into the 21st Century''. Gregory first became a vegetarian in the 1960s and lost a considerable amount of weight by going on extreme fasts, some lasting upwards of 50 days. He developed a diet drink called "Bahamian Diet Nutritional Drink" and went on TV shows advocating his diet and to help the morbidly obese. ==== Animal rights ==== In 2003, Gregory and [[Cornel West]] wrote letters on behalf of [[People for the Ethical Treatment of Animals]] (PETA) to [[KFC|Kentucky Fried Chicken]]'s CEO, asking that the company improve its animal-handling procedures."[http://findarticles.com/p/articles/mi_m3190/is_47_37/ai_111013629/ PETA Recruits Comedian, Activist in Anti-KFC Push]," ''Nation's Restaurant News'', November 24, 2003. ==== Pollution ==== In 2008, Gregory stated he believed that air pollution and intentional water contamination with heavy metals such as lead and possibly manganese may be being used against black Americans, especially in urban neighborhoods, and that such factors could be contributing to high levels of violence in black communities.{{cite web|url=http://www.cnsnews.com/news/article/dick-gregory-blasts-insane-racist-system-america|title=Dick Gregory Blasts 'Insane, Racist System' in America|date=July 7, 2008|publisher=}} ==== Hunger strikes ==== On September 10, 2010, Gregory announced that he was going on a hunger strike. In a commentary that was published by the [[Centre for Research on Globalisation]] Web site in Montreal, he said that he doubted the official U.S. report about the terrorist attacks on September 11, 2001. {{quote|One thing I know is that the official government story of those events, as well as what took place that day at the Pentagon, is just that, a story. This story is not the truth, but far from it. I was born on October 12, 1932. I am announcing today that I will be consuming only liquids beginning Sunday until my eightieth birthday in 2012 and until the real truth of what truly happened on that day emerges and is publicly known.{{cite news|title=WTC 1 and 2: Justice and 9/11 Demands Accountability. Forensic Evidence Indicates Presence of Controlled Demolition Material|url=http://www.globalresearch.ca/index.php?context=va&aid=20979|work=GlobalResearch.ca|publisher=Centre for Research on Globalisation|location=Montreal|date=September 10, 2010|access-date=2010-09-13}}}} === Health Enterprises, Inc. === In 1984, he founded Health Enterprises, Inc., a company that distributed weight-loss products. With this company, Gregory made efforts to improve the life expectancy of African Americans, which he believed was being hindered by poor nutrition and drug and alcohol abuse.[http://www.aaregistry.org/historic_events/view/dick-gregory-funny-blunt-civil-rights-advocate "Dick Gregory, Funny, Blunt Civil Rights Advocate"], African American Registry. In 1985, Gregory introduced the "Slim-Safe Bahamian Diet", a powdered-diet mix.''[[Ebony (magazine)|Ebony]]'', August 1985, p. 87. He launched the weight-loss powder at the Whole Life Expo in Boston under the slogan "It's cool to be healthy". The diet mix, if drunk three times a day, was said to provide rapid weight loss. Gregory received a multimillion-dollar distribution contract to retail the diet.[http://www.people.com/people/archive/article/0,,20088677,00.html "The Dick Gregory Diet: Lose Weight Fast – Without Fasting – and Get (Him) Rich Quick"], ''People'' archive, September 17, 1984, Vol. 22, No. 12. In 1985, the Ethiopian government adopted, to reported success, Gregory's formula to combat malnutrition during a period of famine in the country.{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=abADAAAAMBAJ&pg=PA13&lpg=PA13&dq=dick+gregory+%22united+nations%22&source=bl&ots=LY5yawosmc&sig=fKLB4kzI0YZ2BepHQkeJgyHlR-c&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwjByrywjujVAhWI6iYKHdymA_8Q6AEIPDAE#v=onepage&q=dick%20gregory%20%22united%20nations%22&f=false|title=Jet|last=Company|first=Johnson Publishing|date=May 27, 1985|publisher=Johnson Publishing Company|language=en}} Gregory's clients included [[Muhammad Ali]]. In 2014, Dick Gregory updated his original 4X formula, which was the basis for the Bahamian Diet and created his new and improved "Caribbean Diet for Optimal Health".{{cite web|title=Caribbean Diet|url=http://www.wellnessinnature.com/|access-date=September 3, 2014}} Some of his health treatments have been described as "unorthodox" and "profitable rot". ==Death== A week prior to his death, Gregory was hospitalized in [[Washington, D.C.]], with a bacterial infection.{{cite web|url=http://abcnews.go.com/amp/Entertainment/wireStory/comedian-civil-rights-activist-dick-gregory-dies-49317506|title=Comedian and activist Dick Gregory dies at 84|publisher=[[ABC News]]|accessdate=August 20, 2017|date=August 19, 2017}} He died at the hospital in Washington, D.C., on August 19, 2017, at the age of 84. The cause was [[heart failure]].{{cite web|url=http://www.hollywoodreporter.com/news/dick-gregory-dead-stand-up-comedy-legend-civil-rights-activist-was-84-1004479|title=Dick Gregory, Trailblazer of Stand-Up Comedy, Dies at 84|work=[[The Hollywood Reporter]]|access-date=August 19, 2017|date=August 19, 2017|author=Mike Barnes}} ==Discography== * ''In Living Black and White'' (1961){{cite web|url=http://www.allmusic.com/artist/dick-gregory-mn0000211197/discography|title=Dick Gregory Album Discography|publisher=''[[AllMusic]]''|accessdate=August 25, 2017}} * ''East & West'' (1961) * ''Dick Gregory Talks Turkey'' (1962) * ''The Two Sides of Dick Gregory'' (1963) * ''My Brother's Keeper'' (1963) * ''Dick Gregory Running for President'' (1964) * ''So You See... In [[Assam]], [[Bengal]] and [[Odisha]], '''Dol Purnima or Dol Jatra''' ; is a major festival. This [[festival]] is dedicated to [[Sri Krishna]]. On this auspicious day, an image of Krishna, richly adorned and besmeared with colored powder ([[Abir]] in Bengali and assam and Odisha), is taken out in procession, in a swinging [[palanquin]], decorated with [[flower]]s, [[leaf|leaves]], colored [[clothes]] and [[paper]]s.<ref>{{cite web|title=Holi (Phalguna-purnima or Dol-purnima)|url=http://ramakrishnamission.org/dol_purnima.htm}}</ref> The procession proceeds forward to the accompaniment of music, blaring of [[conch shell]]s, trumpets and shouts of 'Jai' (victory).
Dol Purnima becomes all the more significant for Bengalis, because this is also the birthday of [[Chaitanya Mahaprabhu]] (1485–1533). He was a great [[Vaishnava]] [[saint]], who popularized modern [[sankirtana]]. He elevated the passion of [[Radha and Krishna]] to a high [[spirituality|spiritual]] plane. He underlined the emotional at the cost of the ceremonial side of devotion. Followers of [[Chaitanya School of Vaishnavism]], believe Chaitanya to be the manifestation of Krishna. Chaitanya Mahaprabhu believed that the essence of [[sadhana]] is always the loving remembrance of [[Hari]]. {{citation needed|date=December 2017}}
'''Days of Celebration'''
The first day of Deul is known as gondh .In the evening time, the full incarnation of Lord Vishnu, god Krishna become ready to visit Ghunucha’s (one of the wife of Krishna) place. His followers make a bonfire in front of the kirtan-ghar and with the beat of Vaishnavite drums, cymbals, idol of Krishna carried round the firework and then to the doul. During the festival, all the regular religious functions of kirtan ghar (prayer house) are performed.
The second day of Deul is known as Bhor-Deul – meaning main Dol. Bhor Deul is celebrated for just one day in the month of Chot and two three days in the month of Phalgun. The idols are coloured with faku on this day.
The third day of Deul is also spent in the same manner as that of the second day.
The last and the fourth day of Doul festival is called Sueri. On that day, god Krishna is supposed to go back to the house of mother Lakshmi from the house of Ghunucha .Devotees bring down god Krishna to a palanquin (dola) and carried in a procession. Participation of people from various regions creates a sea of devotees there. In the rhythm of the Vaishnavite drums, cymbals, conches, etc., Holi songs rend the sky. People throw coloured powders to one another. When the procession arrived at kirtan ghar, the gate is block with bamboos by the followers of Mother Lakshmi. It is believed that, Mother Lakshmi become angry with her husband god Krishna, because He stayed at Ghunucha’s place for all these days. The followers of Mother Lakshmi therefore stop the opposite group from entering her house. But at last, the bamboos are broken and Lord Krishna entered the campus and takes seven round of kirtan ghar. ‘He tires and takes rest for a while. Taking advantage of the peace, a devotee from Lakshmi’s side ‘reproves’ him; one of his devotees returns the reproof. An interesting verbal duel thus ensues. In the end he admits defeat, like a peace loving husband, satisfies her with money and other presents and earns His admittance into the shrine. There ends the great Deul festival’ (Das, 1972:89-90).
The 2018 date is March 1.<ref>http://www.festivaldatetime.co.in/2016/05/2018-holi-festival-date-time-in-india-dol-purnima-2018-dates.html#axzz575aDJ2uk</ref>

'''Einer Nielsen''' (1894–1965) was a Danish physical [[mediumship|medium]] and [[Spiritualism|spiritualist]].<ref>[[Paul Kurtz|Kurtz, Paul]]. (1985). ''A Skeptic's Handbook of Parapsychology''. Prometheus Books. p. 475. {{ISBN|978-0879753009}}</ref><ref name="Kragh 2003">Kragh, Jesper Vaczy. ''Danish Spiritualism, 1853–2012''. In Christopher M. Moreman. ''The Spiritualist Movement: Speaking with the Dead in America and Around the World''. ''Volume 1: American Origins and Global Proliferation''. [[Greenwood Publishing Group|Praeger]]. pp. 77–78. {{ISBN|978-0-313-39947-3}}</ref>
==Life== Nielsen was born in [[Copenhagen|Copenhagen, Denmark]]. He travelled in [[Europe]] giving [[séance]]s and claimed to be able to produce spirit [[Materialization (paranormal)|materializations]].<ref>[[Lewis Spence|Spence, Lewis]]. (2003). ''Encyclopedia of Occultism & Parapsychology''. Kessinger Publishing. p. 652. {{ISBN|978-0766128170}}</ref> He was originally investigated by the Danish Society for Psychical Research who produced a favourable report of his mediumship. However, the report was disputed by other researchers. Norwegian investigators suspected Nielsen to be a fraud and investigated him in 1922. The committee from the [[University of Oslo|Kristiania University]] discovered that his [[ectoplasm (paranormal)|ectoplasm]] was fake.<ref name="Kragh 2003"/><ref>Universitetskomiteen, Mediet Einer Nielsen, kontrolundersøkelser av universitetskomiteen i Kristiania (Kristiania 1922). Anonymous. ''Rapport fra den av Norsk Selskab for Psykisk Forskning nedsatte Kontrolkomité''. Norsk Tidsskrift for Psykisk Forskning 1 (1921–1922), pp. 110–125.</ref> Due to the new report by the Norwegians which was negative and covered strongly by the Danish [[news media]], the original report by the Danish Society for Psychical Research was seen as an embarrassment and several members resigned from the society.<ref name="Kragh 2003"/>
The psychical researcher [[Harry Price]] sat with Nielsen in [[Copenhagen]] with "unsatisfactory results."<ref>Chapter ''The Mechanics of Mediumship''. In [[Harry Price]]. (1939). ''Fifty Years of Psychical Research''. Longmans, Green & Co.</ref> Nielsen was also caught hiding his ectoplasm in his [[rectum]].<ref>Brower, M. Brady. (2010). ''Unruly Spirits: The Science of Psychic Phenomena in Modern France''. University of Illinois Press. p. 171. {{ISBN|978-0252077517}}</ref> In 1932, Johs Carstensen the leader of Nielsen's spiritualist circle wrote a pamphlet which exposed his tricks.<ref>Carstensen, Johs. (1932). ''Spiritismens Princip og Fejlgreb. Specielt: Afsløring af Mediet Einer Nielsen''. Brandmose's Forlag.</ref> Nielsen continued to work as a medium until his death but was never considered credible again by people outside his small circle of influence. He published the book ''Solid Proofs of Survival'' in 1950.<ref>Nielsen, Einer. (1950). ''Solid Proofs of Survival''. Translated by [[Helmi Krohn]]. London: Psychic Book Club.</ref>
